string.text: Located just down river from the confluence of the rivers Aver and Lammer, the town of Streissen is known for its revolutionary spirit and volatile past. The town hosts a small university and medical school, infamous for producing pupils who do not abide by the old ways. Streissen once held its own town charter, granting many tax exemptions and the ability to elect its own leaders, but this was revoked in a deal with the Countess Ludmilla Alptraum who saved the town from a student-led revolution. The university continues to operate with the memory of the purge following the Alptraum’s violent suppression still fresh in most residents’ minds. A ferry providing access across the Aver operates here.

Lengenfeld serves as the primary holding of Countess Carmilla von Sachs. The people here fish the river Aver for sustenance, drying and trading the rest along with their cattle to create wealth. A ferry here is also maintained to facilitate travel and trade across the Aver, a tax is collected for their lord.

On the western border of the Wailing Woods is the village of Bieswang. The people here survive off of what they can grow and trade to purchase what they cannot. Unlike most Averlanders, their proximity to a supposedly cursed wood has made the lot of them superstitious; newcomers may be hard pressed to earn their trust.

Sat on the crossroads of the Old Dwarf Road, the town of Heideck was originally constructed by the Dwarfs during the height of their kingdoms several millennia ago. The few still-standing dwarf structures remain in use by the humans here, a living testament to the architectural standards of the elder race. Below Heideck is rumoured to be many dwarf catacombs, filled with ancient treasure and artefacts just waiting to be unsealed and taken.

Surrounded by a ditch and a stone palisade is the town of Colmfӓhre. This is a modest town and is ruled by Baron Sigmund Hindenberg, who maintains his vigil over the settlement and the surrounding area from Castle Hindenburg, situated on a nearby hill. A ferry serves travellers seeking to cross the Reik river, heading south into Wissenland or north into Averland.

As a small town in southern Averland, Loningbruck serves as a crucial stop for merchants travelling along the Reik, either downriver towards Marienburg and the Great Ocean or upriver to the Dwarfen Kingdoms. One of the only roads leading to and from the Blackfire Pass also passes through Loningbruck. As a result of these mercantile interests, the town’s economy relies on the trade these routes bring, supplemented only by the sale of cattle. The town is dominated by The Crossed Keys, a large coaching inn, and the temple of Verena, the largest temple in town. Loningbruck unfortunatly also lends its name to Loningbruck Ruby, a infamously low-quality type of wine.

Home to the Baroness Alder, the unassuming village of Bernloch is most famous for its Bernloch Hard Cheese. The people here mostly raise goats for both their meat and their cheese, as well as facilitate trade along the Agbeiten-Heideck Road.

The docks here at Hochsleben mark the end of the Upper Reik for boat traffic. While the river continues higher into the mountains for many miles, past this point the rapids, falls and ascent becomes far too dangerous for travel. As a result the town typically hosts a number of boats and ships, all plying their trade in goods going to or coming from the World’s edge mountains.

Agbeiten is a large village that serves as both a mercantile and religious hub in Southern Averland. The Taalebenplatz, the centre of Agbeiten, is a large square where Agbeiten holds its daily market located at the crossroads of the Loningbruck-Hochsleben and Heideck Roads. On the northern end of the square are shrines to Sigmar, Ulric, and Verena. The round, timberbuilt Temple of Taal and Rhya is one of the largest in the Southern Empire and one of the few located within the stone walls of a town. The people of Agbeiten are mostly followers of Taal and Rhya.

The small village of Zell was founded on one of the feeding tributaries of the Blue Reach. While the water here is too shallow for larger trading vessels, which are common to other rivers, the villagers use small boats and rafts to transport their crops to Fallenblatt, where it can be sold to the Halflings or transported further down river.

Dietfurts supplies grain to the surrounding settlements as well as for the stores in Pfunzig. The villagers here are suspicious of newcomers, fearing they are halfing spies or worse; travellers from eastern Stirland. Count von Heine hires many of his troops from Dietfurts, many of whom return home when they retire, as a result the men of Dietfurts make for excellent soldiers.

Biberhof lies surrounded by thick forest just a few kilometers south of Wurtbad. Its inhabitants have become quite skilled in the use of the axe, both to harvest high quality wood from the old trees around it and defending their camps from vermin and the occasional highwayman. The timber from Biderhof is sought after by the nobility of Wurtbad, as it is said its dark hues is anathema to any vampire unlucky enough to be skewed by a stake made from this wood.

Julbach is located halfway between River Stir and River Aver. It sits in a valley shadowed by the Zaya hills where sheep roam freely along Nuln road. The Nattern Forest, a few miles to the West, serves as both a source of wealth and superstition, as even in the coldest nights of winter, when both insect and beast sleep, a rumble of hooves can be heard in the distance.

Oberwil is a small fishing village a few miles West of Wurtbad. The routes to Oberwil are little more than footpaths, as most trade and travel is done via river. The village is somewhat protected by the Riverwardens who frequent the Stir, but villagers generally have to fend for themselves against bandits and beastmen from the dark forest.

Tarshof is situated on the Northern edge of the Stirhügel hills. The village enjoys plenty of traffic from traders travelling between Wurtbad and Wörden along the Old Dwarf Road. As a result almost every house in the village professes to be an Inn, although the hospitality varies wildly and travellers are as likely to find themselves sleeping on a pile of hay as a proper pallet bed.

Flensburg is a small market town nestled in the Zaya Hills to the West of the Stirhügel. The hills are perfect for sheep grazing, and the town’s economy is based on fleece, lamb and mutton. The town is also noted in the region for having a major temple of Shallya.

Lochen is a subsidiary settlement of the nearby town Flensburg. The village mostly consists of farmers who supply the market town with grain. Lochen falls under the protection of Countess Petra Harden and her troops.

Franzen is a somewhat unremarkable town, sitting in the shadow of large settlements nearby. It has a healthy fishing trade from the Lammer and the Aver, and also boasts a well-used ferry across the Lammer which allows travellers to continue the road West to Russbach.

Chrobok is a small farming community situated in the low wetlands between the rivers Mattid, Lammer and Aver. The natural irrigation provided by the rivers has made the region perfect arable land, and the nearby Franzen and Averheim enjoy a bountiful supply of grain from the village.

Russbach is a hamlet situated in the sodden fens to the South of the Stirhügel hills. Just beneath the surface of the earth are deep clay pits, and the people of Russbach make a living by mining the building material. Travellers know they’re near the village when they can smell the acrid smoke of the brickmakers’ kilns.

Halstedt Keep is on the South-East edge of the Stirhügel hills and is a staging point for the Roadwardens of the region. Originally it was a manor house belonging to some long forgotten lord, over time it has become more fortified as each subsequent owner has sought to protect its inhabitants against bandits and the greenskins from nearby Altern Forest. Eventually it fell into state hands, and was turned into a fortress lodge for the official Roadwardens who protect the locale.

Raab is a village which formed naturally around a Shallyan Shrine. Situated at the confluence of many roads, it was a natural place for a roadside shrine - a place for travellers to stop, rest and ask for blessings on their journey. One day a wine merchant who frequented the shrine realised the value of such easy custom, and built an Inn at the crossroads. It wasn’t long until a community had built up around it, and the village of Raab was formed.

Tenneck is a village of vintners who supply the local Roadwarden stronghold at Halstedt Keep. Tennech formed from the families of bondmen who tended to the grounds and nobles living at Halstedt Manor. When Halstedt Manor was turned into Halstedt Keep, they were made into freemen, and decided to cultivate their land for selling fruit and drink. The Roadwardens of Halstedt Keep often accept a few gallons of wine a month in exchange for keeping the people of Tenneck safe.

Swartzhafen is a small village notable for its history. A great battle was fought here almost five hundred years prior, the ruins of a castle and the old village to the east of the settlement purportedly all that physically remains of that conflict. The modern village is prosperous, but wary of outsiders due to its situation near Sylvania.

Naubonum is a small village right on the border of Sylvania. The people here get by mostly by raising crops to feed themselves, with any other goods purchased through the sale of excess crops or labour. Situated near the Haunted Hills, the inhabitants are often worried about outsiders from the east, Spectres and foul creatures. The Halfling Fieldwardens are known to stop in the settlement from time to time while patrolling the eastern reaches of the Moot.

The small town of Bylorhof has recently reentered the fold of the holy after throwing off their Sylvanian overlords. The cult of Bylorak, God of the marshes west of town, is the predominant belief of the inhabitants and Bylorak’s priests have taken charge of the town and its affairs, seeking greater support and reintegration with Stirland. There are four small temples in the town dedicated to Bylorak, Morr, Sigmar and Shallya respectively. The old lords castle lies in ruins to the west of town, right next to the Bylorhof Marshes.

A prosperous forest village situated between the Hunger Wood and the Svarsee, the people here at Sterniste make most of their wealth from cutting the local timber and floating it up the Eschenstir to Siegfriedof for market. The people here are very devoted to Morr, having often called upon the Raven Knights to defend them from Goblins and other dangers of the nearby woods or threats from even farther afield.

Vierstein is a small village situated on the southern side of the marshy Morfens, within the Eschenstir basin. The people here are highly isolated from the outside world, only interacting with the wider Empire when they make their voyages to Siegfriedhof to sell their dried fish. The Viersteiners are also known for being excellent marksmen, often serving as bowmen or scouts for the Raven Knights.

Kaunitz is a small hamlet in the far south of Stirland. The people here make most of their living out of cultivating the hilly land surrounding their town, supplemented with what ore they can scrape out of the earth. Most travellers and their goods are welcomed in Kaunitz and Dwarfs often pass through here on their travels out of the mountains and into the wider Empire. However the people are wary of queer folk and will not hesitate to run a Strigany camp or other such rubbish out of their home.

Marburg is a small village on the road between Wurtbad and Siegfreidhof. The village is known for its swine and crops which can help feed many of the nearby communities and towns following a good harvest. Unfortunately the village’s proximity to the Great Forest means frequent incursions by its denizens, and subsequently poorer harvests.

Sigmaringen is the first of seven temples to Sigmar which follows the original path taken by the first emperor into the black mountains to slay Sharanorak, a first-born Dragon Ogre. The people here make most of their money hosting the pilgrims and supplying them with food and equipment for their trek up into the mountains.

Wördern is a small town hidden between mountains and valleys. The rough terrain makes expansion near impossible, but the intersection of the Old Dwarf Road and the Prager strasse makes passing along viable; not that it matters, as no outsider finds kindness in Wörden. The odd mootlander can occasionally be seen purchasing supplies for the road, but its main attraction is the Wörden Meat and Cattle auction house. It’s the only town in Stirland that can be smelled before it is seen.

Kelham is isolated among the hills of the Old Dwarf Road. Its secluded location allows the inhabitants to peacefully farm wheat and other cereals. Its golden fields go just about the start of Altern Forest, where the fertility of the land drops inexplicably. Whatever is not used for local consumption is sent out along the Moot Road to the rest of eastern Stirland and, ultimately, the Mootlands.

Marberg Castle lies to the south of Mittlenburg near the pilgrim trail leading to the seven temples of Sharanorak. The castle was erected to safeguard the passes leading out of the World’s Edge mountains for Dwarf traders as well as to watch over the territory north of the Black Fire Pass.
Gipfel, A small village in the heart of the Greenleaf Hills.

The town of Drakenhof was once considered a beacon of culture within the Empire. But after the sinister takeover of Sylvania by the Vampire Counts, the formerly tall and inspiring spires of Castle Drakenhof now loom menacingly over the townspeople of Drakenhof. The people of Drakenhof are oppressed under the thumb of the Von Carstein lineage. They use the town of Drakenhof to hide their dangerous and other worldly possessions. The people exist as snacks for passing vampires. And every dark corner is the lair for myraid and unspeakable evils. Praying on the townsfolk from dusk till dawn.

Nachthafen is a very uninteresting place. Which is just as it’s ruler Countess Gabriella von Bundebad prefers. Nachthafen does not get involved in the petty squabbles of vampiric intrigue. Nor does it seek war with the Empire. It exists purely as a quiet, normal village. With nothing to see here. Just tasty villagers minding their business until it is time for the masters to feed.

Folburg was the site of a minor rebellion by mortal villagers against their vampiric overlord. Despite gruesomely ripping apart Count Aduhl von Kohnfried with his dying breath he left a curse. The flesh of the villagers began slowly rotting away. But their lives would not leave this mortal coil. The villagers found themselves eternal slaves to a dead master. Now they are maddened skeletons roaming their old dwellings. Pretending to a cheap parody of life. And you better not remind them of what they are.

Gerhof does not sleep. It’s paranoid vampire Count Johan von Goal has forbidden it. A trickster Crone allegedly put a curse on the count. But none other than the Count himself can verify this. It has been said that a sleeping mortal would slay von Goal in a brutal fashion. So von Goal banned sleep. The mortal citizens are skittish. Sneaking an hour or two’s nap in the dark corners of the city. Ordered to be ever watchful for the one who would slay their fearful ruler.

There are tales of Castle Templehof. At one point in history it was the home of the cruel Countess Emanuelle von Templehof. During a dark and terrible battle with the Dwarfs besieging her home Countess Emanuelle bathed her castle in profane magic. Causing an everlasting night to envelop the surrounding area. The indomitable Dwarfs persisted however. Despite many losses they slew the wicked Countess within Castle Templehof. Her anguished screams were said to echo throughout the halls long after the Dwarfs left runes to repel dark magic. Recently, it has become known that some of those runes have faded. And dark things stir within the castle again. Lead by a chorus of screams.

The town of Templehof has seen many nightmarish things. Formerly under the auspices of the Vampire Countess Emanuelle von Templehof the village has recently become the home to a group of Light Mages. Whilst the townsfolk cling to these people as saviours they still whisper of a phantom. The tale of Whispering Nell is well known amongst the townsfolk. A foul spectre who haunts the town and surrounding area. Stealing children and killing Men. Almost as if she owns the place.

Vanhaldenhof is a miserable blot on the map of Sylvania. Originally constructed to guard the castle of Vanhaldenschlosse and it's master, the Necromancer Frederick van Hal. After that castle fell into ruin the village remained as an area for the vampires of Sylvania to feed on it's inhabitants and torment them. The villagers treated as little more than free roaming cattle.

Yet another blighted and miserable place. The villagers treated as little more than snacks from nearby Von Carsteins. Though rebellion has fermented in Mikalsdorf it has been put down so many times that the villagers are wretched, sad things. Shuffling around with no hope for any rescue.

Though unassuming at first, Hundham is a place of whispered rumours. It is said that the dead walk freely on it’s streets. As if mimicking the appearance of life. Others say puppets dance the night away, stringless and alive somehow. No one knows for sure for few have braved it’s narrow streets, it’s dusty shops, or it’s surprisingly open and inviting tavern. But all who go near have warned others to never approach Hundham in the night. For that is when bands of Vampires emerge to dance and make merry. And they’d just love to have a flushed and oh so juicy mortal to dance with.

Fort Oberstyre was once a small but mighty fortress of the Empire. Built shortly after the defeat of Vlad von Carstein in the siege of Altdorf during one of the great Vampire wars of 2010 IC. However, many centuries later after neglect and lack of manpower the fortress was easily taken by Konrad von Carstein. Though the Empire reclaimed the fort it was taken again many years later by Mannfred von Carstein. Who put a terrible curse on the fort. Whenever it is sieged the wrathful specters of past wars rise to kill any and all who threaten the fort. Those spirits lay claim to the fort. And the Empire has been unsuccessful at reclaiming it since.

The oddest thing about Murieste is that it’s people do not follow the religion of Sigmar. Nor any other state approved religion. In fact, the lowly villagers of Murieste worship the vampires around them as gods. Coverting their dark power and hoping to become one of their dark kin. The Vampires in the area tolerate this. Seeing the pathetic peasants as amusing cattle. Vampires do love to play with their food.

Known for being a favourite haunt of Vampires looking to drag their victims off for a good torture session, the screams heard from Fort Bracher can be heard for miles around. Bracher is often fought over by Vampire counts. All of them looking for a new lair from which to torment Men of the Empire.

Most Vampire Counts leave Stoodhof alone, It has been ruled efficiently as a slaughterhouse for human cattle by it’s ruler. From the outside it simply looks like another mud covered village in the middle of this desolate land. From which very little is known about.

Renowned for it’s tapestries made of human flesh. Nachtschlosse is a place of wanton butchery and desolation. With darkness around every corner and in every hall of it’s cursed interior. Monsters freely roam the corridors. Looking for new victims to try their latest stitching patterns on.
Gallhof is often a favourite haunt of Brettonian Blood Knights. Used as a training camp and feasting hall for these bloodthirsty creatures.

Senkhof is one of the last bastions of free humans in Sylvannia. Despite officially being under the dominion of the Vampire Counts, human adventurers and crusaders often use Senkhof and it’s surrounding town to stage conflicts against their vampiric masters. Or at least as a base from which to look for treasure.

Senkhof is one of the last bastions of free humans in Sylvannia. Despite officially being under the dominion of the Vampire Counts, human adventurers and crusaders often use Senkhof and it’s surrounding town to stage conflicts against their vampiric masters. Or at least as a base from which to look for treasure.

Mere months before the Vampire wars. A sorcerer of Nurgle cursed the surrounding village with a plague. The nobility of Wartenhof barricaded themselves in the castle. The villagers begged for salvation as their flesh swelled and burst from deadly boils. But the nobility cared little for them. Inside the castle, the nobles slowly went insane. Becoming cultists of Nurgle within their isolated walls. They were slain by the Vampires as they took over Sylvannia. But the scars of Nurgle’s rot still remain.

As the nobles of Wartenhof locked themselves away, the blighted souls of Wartenhof village slowly succumbed to the sickness of Nurgle’s Rot. Many simply died. They were lucky. For Nurgle sees his sickness as a blessing and gift. And one must be alive to experience it all. When the Vampire Counts came for Wartenhof, the few villages left gladly bound themselves to vampiric service in exchange for a cure. As their service wavers the rot returns. So the Villagers do their best to remain loyal.

This swampy village is isolated from most of Sylvannia. Crossable only by boat, the houses are on stilts and it is very hard for any vampire to find purchase within Sumpdorf. The villagers and farmers know they are safe from the zombies that haunt the Dark Moor. But the local Vampire Counts still come by air from Wartenhof Castle to collect the blood tax.

Grissenwald is the northernmost settlement in Wissenland, right along the banks of the Reik. South of the beginning of the Vorbergland Canal System as well as the southern extent of the Reikwald forest. The Dwarf Shanty, ‘Kazid Slumbol’ sits against the south side of its palisade, and is mostly home to transient Dwarf traders and caravanners, resting here with their more permanent kin before continuing on their routes. Many hunters, trappers and woodcutters make their residence here and during the day will go north into the Reikwald to make their living. The Southern Reikwald is known for being particularly infested with monsters and ne'er do wells. As a result the ruler of Grissenwald, Count Bruno Pfeifraucher, is a professional military man who is often seen leading a patrol around his town to keep the forest’s dangers at bay.

Rohrhausen is an isolated Wissenlander village known for its excellent vineyards, popular even in some of the best taverns in Nuln. This is in part thanks to the cool waters of the River Griss, which come out of the mountains near Rohrhausen.

Wissenburg is the capital of Wissenland and, while it might not carry the economic or cultural weight of Nuln, it is truly the centre of the people. The folk here are the epitome of those virtues which makes Wissenlanders unique from the rest of the Empire. The boughers, artisans and labourers go about their business with thrift and daur pragmatism, speaking clearly and in short direct sentences. Unlike in Altdorf or Nuln, the people here have no time for poetic or flowery expressions. Most of the citizens work the various temples in the city into their daily routine, picking one each day and paying their respect if only for a few minutes, allowing them to pay respect to most of the principal gods each week. Wissenburg is also the last stop for river trade on the upper Reik before Nuln and is surrounded by good farmland. Elector-Countess Emmanuelle von Liebwitz seldom journeys to Wissenburg, coming only to meet the ‘po-faced boughers’ which sit on the Assembly of Wissenland. As a result, while the town is ruled in her name, Baroness Toppenheimer has been given more and more control over the province as a whole.

On the Border of the Grey Mountains, along the shores of the River Wissen is the village of Dotternbach. The Wissenlanders here are shepherds used to climbing high into the lands west of their homes, and as such make strong recruits when they have the young men to spare.
Halgerbach is an isolated Wissenlander village right on the traditional border with Old Solland. It sits on the shores of the River Wissen, which the people here use to irrigate their crops.
On the western shore of the River Soll, at one of the only nearby ferries across the river, is the village of Durbheim. The Sollanders here tend sheep to provide wool to nearby Pfeildorf.

Bernau is your typical Sollander village; the people here are mostly shepherds who raise sheep for their wool. They sell this wool at nearby Pfeildorf for a decent price and are happy with their modest living.

On the eastern shore of the River Soll is the Sollander village of Sexau. The people here are not very well off, and typically can only grow enough food to feed themselves. What extra they do produce is taken to market at Pfeildorf.

Across the River Soll from Kreutzhofen is the small village of Weilerberg. The closeness of the two communities results in a great many ties between them. For instance the town grave digger for Kreutzhofen, Boris Hippler, makes his residence here in Weilerberg.

The Sollanders of Serrig are simple people and are proud of it. Asking any of the shepherds here if they have any greater aspirations than sheep will elicit a round of laughter followed by the statement that: ‘my family has been here since the fall of Solland, not even a Daemon could make me abandon our trade!’

Owingen is a small Wissenlander farming community on the shore of the lower River Soll, just south of a small marshy confluence caused by the lower Soll meeting with the Soll. The people here sell much of their grain to nearby Karak Norn in return for coin and drink, though they will sell you what grain they have to spare.

Heisenberg is well renowned for its deep red wines, which are shipped and sold from Pfeildorf to Kislev. The Wissenlander winemakers here credit the upper River Soll for irrigating their land, as well as the fair winds out of the Granite pass, for the quality of their fruit.

Along the shore of the lower River Soll is the village of Augen. At one time this land would have been populated by Sollanders, but today this part of Sudenland is home to Wissenlanders. The people here can trace their roots back at least three centuries and are very experienced farmers. Augen is well used by passersby, as the village sits on the Granite Pass road, the main route between Meissen and Karak Norn.
Kelgard is a small Wissenlander village on the western shore of the upper Soll. The people here mostly mine the nearby mountains for Iron ore.

To the north of Geschburg is Fluorn, an old Sollander village that has been on the maps since before the fall of Solland. The people here carry on the traditions of Solland, and even have a small shrine to Myrmidia.

To the south of Geschburg is Althausen, a Sollander village populated mostly by shepherds. The land here is also good for vineyards, and while the Althausen vintage hasn’t become renowned outside of the region, it is well received in Geschburg.

Sochtenau is a relatively new community, established within the last few generations as an attempt by the people of Solland to restore some of their former glory. Like many Sollanders, they seem to carry the weight of their past on their backs and in their bones, but they take pride in their work and look after their sheep with thrift and efficiency.

Steingart was once a moderately sized city. With the destruction of old Solland, what remains of Steingart today is but a husk of what used to be. Around the present day town can be found the eight hundred year old ruins. In Steingart, the oppressive air that hangs around the Sollanders is the heaviest, as if they’d be happier if they could just forget their former grandeur. To the south of Steingart is a set of ancient standing stones, commonly called ‘Taal’s Fangs.’ This name is in spite of the insistence of the cult of Taal that the site is not Taalite in origin. A ferry across the River Oggel is here, in the direction of Mendelhof.
Near Waldbach is the small Wissenlander settlement of Moasach. The people of Moasach provide for themselves by raising pigs.

Within sight of the wall in Agbeiten is the Wissenlander village of Ballenhof. The people here are friendly, but have a deep mistrust of Averlanders, saying: ‘they refuse to ev’r sign a contract, take me at my word they say, on their ‘oner they say. I tell em if I’m to take em on their ‘oner, then I need the Crowns and Shillings now!’

Irrigated by the River Soll, the Sollanders here at Eigenhof are able to grow a large quantity of grain and other foodstuffs, which they often take to Wursterburg to be loaded onto a ship and sold farther north.
Nestled in the hills to the northwest of Wusterburg is the Sollander village of Rötenbach. The people here are mostly shepherds, and have been known to range their sheep as far as Serrig.
Salmfahre is a small Wissenlander farming community along the shores of the upper River Soll. It is protected from danger by nearby Nehren.
Trulben is a small Sollander village that primarily gets by through the wool trade. The shepherds here often work with the shepherds of Rotenbach and Serrig.

Near the mountainous source of the River Sonne is the village of Scharmbeck. The people here are hardy mountain dwelling Sollanders, who make their living either by working in the mine at nearby Tierhügel or by raising cattle in the small plain to the northwest of the settlement. On the rise just north of the village centre is a ring of ancient standing stones.
On the Sonnefurt-Wursterburg road is the village of Thalfang, which cuts timber and entertains passerbys.

Merfeld is a village in the Oggelland and as a result is part of the land held in dispute between Averland and Wissenland. To the north of Merfeld is the bridge over the upper Reik to Hocheleben, to the south is the village of Jengen.

Jengen is a small community in the Oggelland that in recent years has found itself in the middle of a dispute between Wissenland and Averland. By an ancient treaty the division between Wissenland and Averland is set south of the upper River Reik and fifty leagues east of the River Oggel. Unfortunately, the upper Reik is known to change its course regularly and leagues are no longer used in the Empire in favour of the Imperial Mile. The fertile, well watered grasslands of the Oggeland is greatly desired by both the Wissenland Sheep Herders, and the Averland Cattle Ranchers; brawls or even ‘battles’ have been known to commence between the two groups. Rancher and Herder alike have petitioned their lords to settle this dispute, with the sword if need be.

Osterzell is formerly recognized as part of Wissenland, the fort at Mendelhof is there to insure this. Despite these legal realities, the people of Osterzell have always maintained a greater kinship with Averlanders than they have with Wissenlanders or even Sollanders. Should Averland choose to act on the Oggelland dispute, the people of Osterzell would support them.
Pahl is a Sollander village. The people here are mostly shepherds and rely on the production of wool to make ends meet.

Travellers heading by the Icy Wind Pass to or from Karak Hirn inevitably pass through Kroppenleben. Many choose to stop here and spend the night before continuing their journey. The small community of Kroppenleben has no qualms with providing these travellers with shelter, or selling them the furs that local hunters have collected this season. Kroppenleben is on the shores of the River Hornberg, just after the River Aulen has contributed to its flow.
Bedernau is a Sollander village just north across the Soll from Wusterburg. The people here produce just enough food to feed themselves, taking what little they have to spare to market at Wusterburg.
Pforzen is a small community of Wissenlander foresters, who provide wood for many of the nearby settlements.
Mauchen is a small community of Wissenlander foresters, they are known particularly well in Wuppertal, where most of their wood is shipped across the Reik for cutting.
On the road to Staig and Wissenburg from Erbshauen is the small fishing village of Ellwangen, whose name comes from an ancient legal requirement for road construction.

A run-down pest hole inhabited by the poorest of the poor, alcoholism and crime are rampant here. The population has around 1200 kislevite immigrants who live in their own slice of heaven called little kislev. The kislevites and the local talabeclanders don’t really interact much.

Upstream of the river Uckro, The villagers of Teupitz are a tight knit community, where everyone adds to the needs of each other. They don’t get many visitors and those that do visit often come to trade for wood from the local lumber mill.

Close to the treeline of the forest that touches talabheim’s crater wall. The villagers of Dreetz keep cows, many shepherds and some veterinarians take care of the great herd of cattle that graze in and around the fields of Dreetz.

Near the mouth of the river Lochra, hence the name, the villagers of Lochrafurt are farmers and pig herders. Water is often carried through the village from the river to provide for the fields and the many pigs that bathe in the mud pits around the village.

A fishing village that borders the river Talabec. Vienau is surrounded by tents that bear the colours of Ostland. However the village of Vienau doesn’t give the ostlanders the treatment that Bek gives them. Even though they outnumber the locals, the village elder has put the immigrants to work, either aiding in the fishing, forming hunter groups, with the local priest’s blessing of course, or farmers.
A small village with a stretch of the great forest to the east and a few hills to the south. Its villagers are mainly woodcutters and eke out a decent existence trading said timber.

Bordering the river Lochra on two sides, Ertburg enjoys the natural protection the river offers from the west and the south. Ertburg is a diverse village, with some hunters, some farmers, some fishermen and a few priests who tend to a small chapel of Taal.

A bustling town along the river Stir and the river kölpin with many of the local populace consisting of woodcutters. There’s alot of taverns for the woodcutters to take a load off after work and all of them are named after the job their patrons have. They have Mourner’s guild, which is dedicated to the Cult of Morr, and is responsible for organising funerals and seeing to the upkeep of the local graveyard.

An unassuming farming village east of the river kölpin, no road leads to Sabritz, instead farmers follow the river south to reach Gersdorf. They don’t care much about this, for they prefer solitude and are quite suspicious of strangers.

Separated from the Barren Hills by a stretch of the Great Forest, Priestlicheim is home to a large Sigmarite monastery, the Temple of Leopold “the Hammer of Faith.” The brothers here are dedicated to the study and eventual eradication of whatever curses the Barren Hills. Although they will explore the hills themselves, they also hire adventurers if other matters demand their attention. The monastery also hunts down any Mutants that wander north out of the hills.

Garndorf is a fortified village with its back to the river Talabec and one side bordering the River Karwe. Garndorf enjoys its natural protection, its land borders protected by a stone wall, Garndorf has a solid strategic position. One can enter Garndorf through a portcullis in the wall or through a ferry across the river Talabec.

The southernmost village of Volgen. Its villagers maintain a big herd of sheep that graze near the barren hills. Despite Priestlicheim’s efforts to stop the supposed hauntings from the barren hills, the odd sheep still goes missing now and again. Despite this the herd remains quite large.

Bordering the river Stir and being at the centre of a crossroads, Missen sees alot of traffic from the surrounding villages. Missen has bits of forest a few ways away and the local populace earns a decent living trading timber.
A community of tree lovers as they’re often described, they give praise to Taal and only use the wood of dead trees, they get by on their meagre farms and foraging in the great forest.

A long way from other towns and villages the village of Ossino is quite poor, despite its decent food stocks. It sees a decent amount of traffic from anyone that comes and goes from Ostermark and sometimes people that travel down the river Stir, but not many wish to stay long in such a desolate looking place. Many requests have been sent to Hermsdorf for tools and supplies to fix the village but not much has been set in motion as of yet.

A village close to a small bit of forest and surrounded by small hills. The villagers of Badau have many farms close to the base of the hills to utilize rainwater flowing down the hills for irrigation.

Bordering a great swathe of the great forest the villagers of Horno are mainly hunters and woodsmen. Horno earns a decent amount of money from the meat and hides they sell and give praise to taal for it.
Slightly wealthier in terms of food and coin than most villages in Talabecland. Klepzig enjoys the protection Castle Ravenstein provides.

Tucked in between two parts of the Great forest, Zurin houses a decent amount of Taal worshippers, often going on pilgrimage to Talabheim or answering Taal’s call. The Fishermen of Zurin often walk north towards the river Uckro to fish, enjoying the walk in the great forest as they do so. Those that remain keep themselves busy with the worship of Taal and tending the farms.

Frederheim is a small Reiklander village just north of Altdorf on the Altdorf-Middenheim road. While the town is a possession of Karl-Franz and is a part of Altdorf’s demesne, the Emperor has seen fit to give oversight of it in all but name to the Cult of Shallya. This is a result of the cult's request for an area in which to establish a walled hospice and sanatorium.

On the eastern side of the confluence of the rivers Taal and Reik sits the village of Kaldach. The town is notable particularly for being the demarcation of the Reikland/Talabecland border. Besides this, it remains a small farming community.

Directly west of Altdorf, between the river Reik and the Weissbruck canal is the village of Hochloff. The town is known for the type of grain it raises the Hochloffkorn which is very well regarded for making a high quality flour.

Holthusen is a town in western Reikland on the river Schilder. By road it lies between Eilhart and Schilderheim. The town's primary trade good is the Holthusen Hogshead barrel which is used across the empire to age or ferment their products before shipment. The barrels are said to be so sturdy as to be able to protect their contents even from direct cannon fire. Every year Holthusen hosts the Weinfest, a great gathering for wine tasting that requires an invite to enter. Of course the lack of invite does not stop the horde of wastrels and rogues who wish to drink the free wine provided by the festival. Weinfest also marks the only time of year during which the Golden Cask is brought out, which is said to contain the best wine in the Empire if not the entire Old World. Due to the town's forested location, it is frequently attacked by beastmen. The palisades and guards are normally strong enough to see the monsters off, but the townspeople fear the day this defence falls short. As such, some of the townspeople have been leaving casks of cheap wine at the edge of the woods in an attempt to appease the beastmen with tribute. This dubious practice likely will not be allowed to continue much longer.

Eilhart remains its mark on the map for one reason; the popularity of its vintage of white wine. Eilhart wine is one of the Reiklands best wines, valued for its crisp light flavours and its mild hangovers. Eilhart is a destination for riverboat cruises, where wealthy merchants and nobles from Altdorf often come up the river to taste the various local vintages and foods. Many of the people here are said to have bretonnian heritage, visitors often comment on the similar bone structure shared by many of the inhabitants.

Ussingen is a small village located on the road between Holthusen and Osburg. The town is at the furthest point that the River Schilder remains navigable by barge, meaning that many shipments bound for Helmgart will arrive first here. The people here raise crops along the river Schilder and will venture into the nearby Grey Mountains to mine seams of ore. The town is well protected by the walls at Helmgart, and really only worries about the denizens of the Reikwald.

Morlenfurt is a small village near the headwaters of the river Bogen. The town is known for its silver mines and the small community of Dwarfs which contribute to the silver trade within the Reikland.

At the foot of the Axe Bite Pass sits the village of Osburg, the last Imperial settlement before the Market fortress of Helmgart and the Imperial/Bretonnian border. Any shipments bound for Helmgart must pass first through Osburg, and this source of trade makes the merchants here fairly prosperous.

To the north northwest of Bögenhafen is the timber producing village of Herzhald. Situated deep in the Reikwald, Herzhald is known for the quality and lengths of its timber samples, much of which is sent to Bögenhafen and Grünburg for their boatbuilding.

Geissbach is a forest village just north of Ubersreik. The people here carefully timber the woods nearby and grow what crops they can in the clearings around the village. For a long time there have been rumors and worries about a dark estate just east of the village, which is said to house great evil.

To the south of Ubersreik is the mining town of Hugeldal. Hugeldal was founded three hundred years after the founding of the empire to mine copper and iron from the Grey mountains. In 1112 IC, town records indicate that the Black Plague devastated the local population and nearly ruined the town. The cult of Shallya saw fit to establish a hospice here shortly thereafter. Not long after the arrival of the Shallyans, the Strigany that have always frequented the area were banned from entering the town. Despite this they regularly pitch camp outside of the palisade to entertain and trade with the locals
Barfsheim is a small village along the river Grissen near the Countess Emmanuelle canal. Its grain often is exported out of the Reikland to feed Grissenwald and Nuln.

Steindorf is a small village near the headwaters of the river Grissen. Its people refuse to travel into the Grey Mountains that often overshadow the village. Despite the fact that the minerals would bring great wealth to the village, the people here speak of a dread castle in the mountains above them, saying that they would rather remain in their vale with their grain.

Naffdrof is an isolated village that sits along the Grey Lady Canal between Stimmigen and Hugeldal. Naffdrof is almost entirely surrounded by a marshland created by the nearby rivers Teufel, Ober and Tranig. In truth there is not much reason to stop in Naffdrof, the village's main commodity is the fish that use the canals to move between the rivers.

Teufelfeuer is a rural village outside of Kemperbad. The village is truly only notable for being the scene where one hundred years ago the forces of the Reikland Clashed with one of the largest hordes of Beastmen to emerge from the Reikwald Forest. The story goes that when the battle wizards through their magical fire towards the monstrosities, the trees around them burst into a devil’s fire with hues not natural to this world. The people here are proud of this story and often hawk the ‘relics’ of this historic battle.

Diesdorf is a small town on the river Reik located between Altdorf and Kemperbad. Diesdorf is a major holy site of the Cult of Sigmar, it is said that Magnus the Pious once made a powerful and stirring speech to the crowds who had gathered to hear him. Around sixty years ago, Emperor Wilhelm III founded the Diesdorf Military college to train those who have proven their leadership abilities in battle.

Lachenbad sits along the Tranig river at the joining points of the Grey Lady and Ober-Stimmigen canals. While the village is a farming community, it is the home of a talented blacksmith, Uli and his promisingly talented son Valten.

Worlitz is a river village protected by the forces garrisoning the Castle Reiksguard. The people here are very loyal directly to the Emperor Karl-Franz who many believe to be a reincarnation of Sigmar. The town benefits from trade heading down the Reik to Altdorf, Marienburg and beyond.

The town of Grünburg sits on the river Teufel. While trade flows through the town from the canals to itself and from the Reik to its north, Grünburg’s main source of wealth comes from its river boatyards, where many of the boats and barges that ply the rivers of the Reikland originate from. The town is also famous for the Battle of Grünburg where the advance of Orc Warlord Gorbad Ironclaw was finally halted around a half a millenia ago. The battle plains is valued particularly due to the fact that nearly all of the Imperial and orc forces present were mounted calvarymen, unusual for both the contemporary period and the modern era. As such an excavation site has been established by several interested parties and many come to look upon their work.

Weissbruck sits on the joining of the Weissbruck Canal and the river Bӧgen. The town once was a major source of coal and iron in the Reikland, the mining of which provided the Gruber family with enough funds to construct the Weissbruck Canal, which enabled easier transportation of the mined material to market. Now the mines have mostly been depleted and while the town continues to have prosperous ventures in trade thanks to the canal, the many former workers of the mine have found themselves unemployed and stuck in Weissbruck, where they spend their time drinking cheap alcohol and causing trouble.
Just to the south west of altdorf is the small village of Heiligen. The village is nothing to speak of, but it is near the amber hills, which offer a spectacular view of Altdorf from their height.

Reinsfeld is a village along the Uhl river in the northwestern Reikwald. The people here are fairly isolated from the rest of the Province, relying on what little trade passes by on the road towards Marienburg.
